[Question]
ok i have social anxiety i m actually quiet smart however when i m in social situation the anxiety is so much my brain go to mush like simple thing like counting money etc is so hard because my heart is beating through my ear i also dissociate ha anyone else experienced this phenomenon when i m by myself i can do all these task easily but in front of people literally become an invalid like it hilarious how people dumb down thing for me sad but all you can do is laugh

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be challenging to navigate social situations when you have social anxiety. It's important to remember that you are not alone in experiencing these feelings. Many people with social anxiety struggle with similar symptoms, such as feeling overwhelmed or struggling to complete simple tasks in front of others.

One strategy that may help is gradually exposing yourself to social situations in a controlled and supportive way. Start by practicing in low-pressure environments, such as with close friends or family members, and gradually work your way up to more challenging situations. This can help build your confidence and reduce anxiety over time.

Deep breathing exercises can also be helpful in managing anxiety symptoms. When you notice your heart racing or feeling overwhelmed, take slow, deep breaths to help calm your body and mind. Focusing on your breath can help bring your attention back to the present moment and alleviate some of the anxiety.

Another technique that might be beneficial is cognitive reframing. Instead of viewing yourself as "dumb" or incapable, try to challenge those negative thoughts and replace them with more positive and realistic ones. Remind yourself of your strengths and abilities, and focus on the progress you've made rather than any perceived shortcomings.

Engaging in self-care activities can also be important for managing anxiety. Find activities that bring you joy and relaxation, whether it's reading, exercising, listening to music, or spending time in nature. Taking care of your overall well-being can have a positive impact on your mental health.

Lastly, consider seeking support from a mental health professional who specializes in anxiety disorders. They can provide personalized guidance and strategies tailored to your specific needs. Remember, there is no shame in asking for help, and taking steps towards improving your mental health is a courageous and important decision.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
for the past year and a half i ve had constant tiredness fatigue and just haven t felt like myself i used to be pretty active always working on project excited about life for the last year and a half i just feel like a shell of myself tired and meh i m also hungry constantly i ve seen my doctor and a few different specialist and had plenty of blood work done including thyroid and everything ha been normal no sleep apnea no anemia no lyme my doc said we have essentially ruled out most if not all straight up medical cause of fatigue beyond the possibility i m just not getting good sleep due to underlying stress or anxiety hard for me to tell how well i m sleeping not waking up refreshed but i m in bed for hr a night i ve begun to wonder if i m simply depressed since everything else ha kind of been ruled out i don t feel very sad and i don t feel hopeless i don t lack the motivation to do all the thing i love i just feel too tired or lazy to do them but i really want to be my old self again if i could snap my finger and have my energy back i d do it in a heartbeat how do i know if i m depressed

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a lot of fatigue and feeling like a shell of yourself for quite some time now. It's understandable that you're feeling concerned and frustrated by this.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that fatigue can be caused by various factors, including medical conditions, lifestyle habits, and emotional stressors. While you mentioned that you've already seen your doctor and had blood work done, it might be worth considering other aspects of your life that could be contributing to your fatigue. For example, are there any changes in your daily routine or environment that could be impacting your energy levels?

In addition to considering medical causes, it's also worth exploring the possibility of stress or anxiety affecting your sleep patterns. Sleep disturbances can often manifest as fatigue during the day. You mentioned that it's difficult for you to assess how well you're sleeping, but there are some simple steps you can take to improve your sleep quality. Establishing a consistent sleep schedule, creating a relaxing bedtime routine, and ensuring your sleeping environment is comfortable and conducive to restful sleep can all contribute to better sleep.

Regarding your question about whether you might be depressed, it's important to remember that fatigue and feeling low on energy are not necessarily exclusive symptoms of depression. However, it's always a good idea to consult with a mental health professional who can provide a thorough evaluation and offer guidance tailored to your specific situation. They can help determine if depression might be playing a role in your symptoms and explore potential treatment options.

In the meantime, you can try incorporating small lifestyle changes to boost your energy levels. Regular exercise, even if it's just a short walk each day, can have a positive impact on your overall energy levels. Additionally, paying attention to your diet and ensuring you're getting proper nutrition can also contribute to increased energy.

Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself as you navigate through this process. It can take time to uncover the root causes of your fatigue and find effective strategies to improve your energy levels.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
for anyone who s contacted the suicide help hotline ha it actually helped i don t think i ll make past this week although i have friend here for me and therapy i ve written all my goodbye and i m ready to do the deed a i ve got nothing left to lose any input is helpful

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great to hear that you've reached out to the suicide help hotline and that it has been helpful for you. It takes a lot of strength to seek support, and I want you to know that there are still steps you can take to navigate through this difficult time.

Firstly, it's important to remember that you don't have to face this alone. While it may feel like you have nothing left to lose, reaching out to your friends and therapist shows that you do have a support system in place. They can provide emotional support and guidance during this challenging period.

Additionally, consider exploring other coping mechanisms or activities that may bring you some comfort or distraction. Engaging in hobbies, exercising, spending time in nature, or practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation can help alleviate some of the distress you may be feeling.

Furthermore, if you find yourself feeling overwhelmed or in immediate danger, please consider reaching out to emergency services or a crisis hotline specifically designed for mental health crises. They can provide immediate assistance and ensure your safety.

Lastly, it's important to keep in mind that thoughts of suicide can be overwhelming, but they do not define your worth or the potential for positive change in your life. While it may feel like there is no hope, there is always hope for recovery and healing.

Remember, you deserve support and care, and there are resources available to assist you. Don't hesitate to reach out to those around you and continue seeking professional help to navigate through this challenging journey.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i live in my bedroom weekend burn by fast with me playing video game i bought a new car but lack will to learn how to get comfortable with it i want to do thing but i don t want to drive myself to these place in fear of crashing into something and my job is easy and amazing pay but somehow i find a way to disdain it and my coworkers i want to start dating again but all the sudden i ve become embarrassed of who i am i feel like i m boring and not really interesting to talk to my coworkers like to find my insecurity and turn it into a joke for everyone and i haven t done anything to them i m just there i feel like i m losing my grip on reality sometimes and just want to end it forever and if i did nothing of value would be lost and nobody would really care i m afraid of change yet i want it so much at the same time i just wish i were a more outgoing person who doesn t let other s word get to me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a tough time right now. It's completely normal to feel this way, and I'm here to support you.

Firstly, it's important to remember that everyone has their own insecurities and fears. You're not alone in feeling this way, even though it may seem like others are making fun of you or judging you. Remember that their opinions are not a reflection of who you are as a person.

When it comes to driving, it's completely understandable to have fears and anxieties. One suggestion I have is to start small and gradually build up your confidence. You could try practicing in an empty parking lot or taking short drives around familiar areas before venturing out on busier roads. This might help you become more comfortable with the car and lessen your fear of crashing.

Regarding your job, it's common to feel disdain towards work at times, especially if you're not fully engaged or satisfied. However, try to focus on finding aspects of your job that you enjoy or find fulfilling. Engaging in conversations with your coworkers about shared interests or hobbies can also help build connections and boost your confidence.

When it comes to dating again, it's natural to feel embarrassed or self-conscious after going through a breakup. However, remember that everyone has their own journey, and it's okay to take your time to heal and rediscover yourself. Start by focusing on self-care and building a strong foundation of self-confidence before considering dating.

Changing habits and embracing new experiences can be challenging, but they can also lead to personal growth and fulfillment. Start small by setting achievable goals for yourself and gradually push yourself out of your comfort zone. Surround yourself with supportive friends or loved ones who can encourage and motivate you along the way.

Remember, change is a natural part of life, and it's okay to feel both excited and afraid of it at the same time. Be patient with yourself and celebrate each step forward, no matter how small. You deserve happiness and fulfillment, and I believe in your ability to overcome these challenges.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i am mentally exhausted i have so many problem that i can not deal with my older brother bully me daily and all i do is just sit and listen to it if i tell him to stop he will just continue to be more annoying i have a lot of health problem my parent dont want to take me to a doctor because they think i am lying so i have to do it myself i am not legal in my country i go to school and put on a fake personality and laugh people bully me even there not physcally but mentally they tell me i am dumb weird skinny crazy i have zero friend in real life i have online friend that used to help me with everything and even made a workout plan for me all of that faded since my health is sucking rn my parent call me crazy daily becayse i like ti play video game for hour a day that is crazy to them even tho everyone else tell them it normal all i feel inside if me is just fear sadness and hopelessness 0 good or happy thought i thoght dozen if time about suicide i can t do it i have ocd and that top of everything and obliderates my life and make me suffer even more i can t take it anymore i don t knoe where to go or what to do it like i don t belong anywhere or cant do anything all i can do is whine on random subbredit because i have no one to talk to is this all life really is i know you might say ohh but if you try to get yourself up and get motivated and do stuff trust me i tried it many time it fails because of family problem etc am i worth saving is my life really worth living

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now. It's important to remember that you don't have to face everything alone and there are people who can support you.

Firstly, it's crucial to prioritize your safety and well-being. If you feel comfortable, consider reaching out to a trusted adult in your life, such as a teacher, counselor, or social worker, who can provide guidance and help you navigate through these challenges. They may be able to offer resources and support specific to your situation.

Additionally, reaching out to a mental health helpline or crisis hotline can provide you with immediate assistance and emotional support. They can help you explore your options and develop a plan for moving forward.

Regarding your health problems, it's essential to advocate for yourself and seek medical attention. While it can be frustrating when your parents don't understand or support your needs, you deserve proper diagnosis and treatment. Consider researching local healthcare providers or organizations that specialize in supporting individuals with mental health issues.

Building a support network is also vital. While online friends can be helpful, it might be beneficial to seek out offline connections as well. Look for local community groups or organizations that align with your interests or hobbies. Engaging in activities you enjoy can help boost your mood and provide opportunities to meet like-minded individuals.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient with yourself and allow yourself to explore different strategies and coping mechanisms. Surround yourself with positive influences and engage in self-care activities that bring you joy and relaxation.

Lastly, please know that you are not alone in feeling this way. There are people out there who care about your well-being and want to see you thrive. Keep reaching out for support, stay connected with those who uplift you, and never underestimate the power of seeking professional help when needed.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
my depression is taking a turn for the worst the thought about offing myself are starting to become more frequent again there s barely anything going on in my life yet my anxiety feel so overwhelming that one would think i live a busy life i feel so hollow all the time and i don t like it it s starting to get to the point where i can t even do anything because my depressive thought just intrude on every part of my day that it s preventing me to actually be productive i have essay to write for my uni class but all i do is stare at my laptop because i can t even cry i attend my lecture and join class discussion because everyone say that engaging in those thing will increase the likelihood i ll pas but i barely remember what s going on at all or what i m saying how do i function to live at least until the semester is over

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions to help you navigate this difficult period.

Firstly, it's important to reach out for support when you're feeling this way. Consider talking to someone you trust about what you're experiencing - a close friend, family member, or even a teacher or counselor at your university. They can provide a listening ear and offer assistance if needed.

In addition to seeking support from others, there are also steps you can take on your own to improve your mental well-being. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can be helpful in combating depression. This might include hobbies, exercise, spending time in nature, or connecting with loved ones. Finding moments of happiness and purpose can make a significant difference in how you feel.

Another strategy that could be beneficial is creating a routine or schedule for yourself. Establishing structure in your day can provide a sense of stability and purpose, even when you may not feel motivated. Start by setting small, achievable goals for each day and gradually increase them as you start to regain momentum.

When it comes to writing your essay, breaking it down into smaller tasks can make it feel more manageable. Set aside specific times during the day to work on your essay, allowing yourself breaks in between to rest and recharge. It may also be helpful to seek resources such as online writing guides or workshops to improve your writing skills and overcome any challenges you're facing.

Remember to prioritize self-care as well. Taking care of your physical health through proper nutrition, regular exercise, and sufficient sleep can have a positive impact on your mental well-being. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing exercises, meditation, or mindfulness can help alleviate anxiety and promote a sense of calm.

Lastly, please keep in mind that everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient with yourself and allow yourself to seek professional help if needed. Remember, you are not alone in this, and there are people who care about your well-being.

I hope these suggestions can provide some guidance and support as you navigate through this challenging time. Remember to reach out for help and prioritize your mental health.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i want to know how to stop anxiety while waiting whenever i have a guest coming over wether it be a friend or family or someone im interested in i get severe anxiety from the moment they say on my way to the moment they arrive i feel hot all over i want to throw up and cry and use the bathroom and then a soon a they arrive and i see them im fine for example i called the man im interested in over for a booty call he life an hour away so at 0 0 he texted me he wa coming for an hour i wa asking my sister should i cancel i want to see him but i m anxious and for that entire hour i wa freaking out the only thing that helped wa sitting in the cold drive way and breathing in the night air and then a soon a he arrived i wa fine absolutely perfect similar happened while i waited for guest to arrive to a house party i wa throwing i need help i am on med and in therapy anything help

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really challenging to experience severe anxiety while waiting for guests to arrive. It's understandable that you feel hot all over, want to throw up, and have the urge to use the bathroom. These physical symptoms are often associated with anxiety.

One suggestion I have is to try some relaxation techniques before your guests arrive. Deep breathing exercises can help calm your body and mind. You can take slow, deep breaths in through your nose, hold it for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. Repeat this several times until you start to feel more relaxed.

Another technique you could try is progressive muscle relaxation. This involves tensing and then releasing each muscle group in your body, starting from your toes and working your way up to your head. This exercise can help release tension and promote a sense of relaxation.

Additionally, it might be helpful to distract yourself during the waiting period. You could engage in activities that you enjoy or find calming, such as listening to music, reading a book, or doing a puzzle. By focusing on something else, you may be able to redirect your attention away from anxious thoughts.

In therapy, your mental health professional can work with you to develop personalized coping strategies for managing anxiety. They can also explore any underlying causes or triggers for your anxiety. Medication can be beneficial in reducing anxiety symptoms, so it's great that you're already on medication.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it's important to find what works best for you. It may take some trial and error to discover the coping strategies that resonate with you. Don't hesitate to reach out to your therapist or healthcare provider for further guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
it will be two year this november since my brother died from a fentanyl overdose this completely shook up the family dynamic i moved back home to be closer to them about a year before his death while i am happy i did get to spend his last birthday with him since he is gone and the family is all split up now i hate living here i used to make double doing the type of work that i do here where i last lived my job is actually financially draining me i am a caregiver aid for disabled kid and have been for over year but ever since my brother died i find myself in very dark place then i get really angry for a second because i know he is gone and never coming back then throw in the caregiver fatigue with the grieving depression and i just feel so crazy in my head sometimes one minute i m fine the next minute i hate everyone inflation isn t helping because i am having to skip meal to make sure my kid are fed which also isn t helping my mental health i dunno how do you all cope

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a lot since your brother's passing, and I can understand how difficult it must be for you. Grief is a complex process, and it's completely normal to feel a wide range of emotions during this time.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge the strength and love you have for your family. Moving back home to be closer to them shows how much you care about their well-being. It's understandable that the family dynamic has changed since your brother's death, and it may take some time for everyone to adjust.

Regarding your job as a caregiver aid for disabled children, it's important to recognize the value and significance of your work. However, it's also essential to prioritize your own mental health and well-being. If possible, consider having an open conversation with your employer about your current situation. They may be able to provide support or explore options that could alleviate some of the financial strain.

In terms of managing caregiver fatigue and grieving depression, finding healthy coping mechanisms is crucial. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help improve your overall mood. This could include hobbies, exercise, spending time with loved ones, or practicing mindfulness techniques such as deep breathing or meditation.

Additionally, seeking support from others who have experienced similar losses can be beneficial. Connecting with a support group or online community where you can share your feelings and experiences may provide comfort and understanding. Sometimes, simply talking about your emotions with someone who listens without judgment can make a significant difference.

Remember, healing takes time, and there is no right or wrong way to grieve. Be patient with yourself and allow yourself to feel whatever emotions come up. If you find that your symptoms persist or worsen over time, it may be helpful to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

[Question]
hello im currently and ive only ever driven on the freeway once wa on for like a minute before i got scared and got off if for any reason i have to use it i ask a friend to take me or i get an uber instead driving in general ha always been scary for me but the freeway is the bane of my existence i feel like at my age it becoming a problem plus it just kind of embarrassing to admit to other people my age haha especially if im asking for a ride if anyone else ha had this problem please let me know what you did to overcome it thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that driving on the freeway can be intimidating, especially if you haven't had much experience with it. It's great that you're seeking advice on how to overcome this fear. Here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Start small: Begin by practicing driving on less busy roads or streets with clear boundaries. This can help build your confidence and make the transition to the freeway easier.

2. Take it slow: When you feel ready, gradually increase your exposure to the freeway. Start with short drives on the freeway and gradually increase the duration as you become more comfortable.

3. Deep breathing exercises: Before getting onto the freeway, take a few moments to focus on your breathing. Deep breathing exercises can help calm your nerves and reduce anxiety while driving.

4. Positive self-talk: Replace negative thoughts with positive affirmations. Remind yourself that you are capable of driving safely and confidently. Encourage yourself with phrases like "I am in control" or "I trust my abilities."

5. Find a support system: Consider reaching out to a friend or family member who can accompany you on drives until you feel more confident. Having someone supportive by your side can provide reassurance and encouragement.

6. Seek professional guidance: If your fear continues to significantly impact your daily life, it may be helpful to consult with a mental health professional who specializes in anxiety or phobias. They can provide personalized strategies and techniques to help you overcome your fear.

Remember, overcoming fear takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate each step forward, no matter how small.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hey friend i come asking question about workplace anxiety i m 9 and work retail i realize that this is a job with low stake and that whatever fear i have about making mistake are rather silly given the nature of the job however i ve worked myself up because i worked an event this evening and in my eye it wa just a series of unfortunate event first i show up early but still later than my coworker who i wa working with for the event he wa talking to our bos second i wa underdressed he looked so sharp granted i am 9 and he is almost a full decade older than me with the life experience to really comprehend dress code it wa rather unspecified and unclear so i m trying not to beat myself up too much about it i ran home super quickly and grabbed some nicer shoe and a jacket but it still wasn t great third my bos gave u her number to text or to call if we needed any help i texted her first and then she asked if i would call her because she wa on the road make sense but i feel i made a mistake texting her in the first place fourth fifth sixth and so on i worry that throughout the entire evening i wad screwing up and ended up losing the store a ton of money i m so upset about everything that happened and being liked by my bos that i wa cry and now i can t sleep please oh please i beg of y all how do i get over this it s making my day really difficult and i don t want this to follow me into the future when if i have a job much more demanding and serious if i mess up it s eating me up and i can t take it thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're really struggling with workplace anxiety, especially after experiencing a series of unfortunate events at your recent work event. It's understandable that these situations have caused you to worry and feel anxious about making mistakes in the future.

Firstly, it's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes, even in low-stakes jobs like retail. Mistakes happen, and they don't always have to be catastrophic. Instead of beating yourself up over these small errors, try to focus on what you can do differently next time to prevent similar issues from occurring.

When it comes to the dress code, it can sometimes be unclear or unspecified, especially if you're new to the job. Instead of second-guessing yourself, consider having an open conversation with your supervisor or colleagues about the dress code expectations. This way, you can gain clarity and ensure you're dressed appropriately moving forward.

Regarding the situation with your supervisor, it might have been better to clarify things directly rather than assuming what she meant by offering her number. When reaching out to her, you could have asked for guidance or advice regarding the event rather than assuming it was related to your performance.

To manage your anxiety, it might be helpful to practice self-care techniques such as deep breathing exercises, mindfulness, or engaging in activities that help you relax. Additionally, consider talking to someone you trust about your feelings and concerns. Sometimes, just expressing your emotions can provide relief and help you gain perspective.

Remember, it's normal to feel anxious in new situations or when facing challenges. However, if these feelings persist and start affecting your overall well-being, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health expert who can provide personalized strategies and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
for the past few day i ve been dealing with extreme bout of anxiety i feel anxious all day nausea all day and i cant seem to stop thinking about negative thought i ve been dealing with a lot of ups and down regarding school and romantic relationship i keep skipping school because my anxiety is way too high i dont know how to calm it down i want to see a psychologist but right now it very hard to get to see one so i ll need all any advice you have thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been going through a really tough time lately, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions to help you manage your anxiety.

Firstly, it's important to remember that you're not alone in this. Many people experience anxiety, and there are strategies that can help alleviate its symptoms. One technique you might find helpful is deep breathing exercises. When you notice yourself feeling anxious, take a moment to focus on your breath. Inhale deeply through your nose, hold for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. This can help activate your body's relaxation response and reduce feelings of anxiety.

Another technique you could try is grounding yourself in the present moment. Anxiety often leads us to worry about the future or dwell on negative thoughts from the past. To counteract this, try bringing your attention back to the present moment. Notice the sensations in your body, the sounds around you, or the objects in your environment. Engaging your senses can help shift your focus away from anxious thoughts.

Additionally, it may be beneficial to challenge negative thoughts that contribute to your anxiety. When you catch yourself thinking negatively, ask yourself if there is any evidence to support those thoughts. Often, our anxieties are based on irrational fears rather than reality. By questioning and reframing these thoughts, you can begin to break free from their grip.

Regarding school and your romantic relationship, it's understandable that these factors are adding to your stress. Consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member who can provide support and understanding during this challenging time. Sometimes talking about our concerns with someone we trust can help us gain perspective and find solutions.

Lastly, while it may be difficult to see a psychologist right now, there are still resources available online that can provide guidance and support. Look for reputable websites or apps that offer self-help tools and techniques for managing anxiety. These resources can provide valuable insights and strategies to help you navigate through this difficult period.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to be patient with yourself as you explore different techniques and find what works best for you. You deserve support and care, and I believe in your ability to overcome these challenges.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i have felt so depressed for year now im only and i ve been through a lot but who hasn t i m just a weak person that can t get over my issue the only thing i m good at is hurting people therapy will never help me because i am never going to change i m a terrible fucking person and i hate myself more than anything it feel like my life is never going to get better and i know that i will never deserve happiness but i feel like i ll truly be happy once i take my last breath

Remember that everyone's journey is unique, and what may seem like a long time to you might not be the same for others.

Firstly, I want to assure you that you are not weak for going through difficult times. Life can be tough, and it takes strength to reach out and share your feelings. It's important to remember that healing takes time and there is no set timeline for when things will get better.

As for the idea of being happy once you take your last breath, it's important to remember that happiness is a subjective state of mind. Firstly, I want to acknowledge the pain and sadness you're experiencing. It's important to give yourself permission to grieve the loss of your friend and the change in your relationship. Allow yourself to feel whatever emotions come up without judgment or pressure to "snap out" of it.

Finding motivation can be challenging when you're feeling unmotivated, but there are steps you can take to gradually regain a sense of purpose and joy. Start by identifying activities or hobbies that used to bring you happiness or fulfillment. Even if you don't feel like engaging in them initially, try to incorporate them into your routine. Sometimes, taking small steps towards doing things we enjoy can help reignite our passion for life.

Additionally, reaching out to others for support can make a big difference. While it may feel like people don't care or understand, there are likely individuals in your life who would be willing to listen and offer their support. Consider reaching out to friends, family members, or even joining support groups where you can connect with others who may have similar experiences.

Lastly, if you find that these feelings persist or become overwhelming, it might be helpful to seek professional guidance from a mental health expert.  It's understandable that you're considering the possibility of either selling or getting rid of most of your things before making any drastic decisions. 1. Take a step back: Before making any major changes, it can be helpful to take a moment to reflect on your feelings and thoughts. Consider why you're feeling this way and if there might be other options available to you.

2. Seek support: While it's great that you don't want any pity, reaching out to someone you trust can provide valuable perspective and emotional support. They can offer guidance and help you explore alternative solutions to your current situation.

3. Review your finances: If you plan on paying off your little debt, it would be beneficial to assess your financial situation. Look into ways to increase your income or create a budget to better manage your money. This can give you a clearer picture of what steps you need to take to address your debt.

4. Consider professional help: If you find that your thoughts of selling or getting rid of your things persist despite your efforts, it may be worthwhile to seek professional help from a mental health therapist or counselor. They can provide you with coping strategies and tools to navigate through these difficult emotions.

5. Take care of yourself physically: Engaging in self-care activities such as exercise, eating well, and getting enough sleep can have a positive impact on your mental health. Taking care of your physical well-being can contribute to an improved overall mood and outlook.

6. Explore creative outlets: Engaging in creative activities like writing, painting, or playing music can serve as healthy distractions and provide a sense of fulfillment. These outlets can also help you process your emotions and gain clarity.

7. Create a plan: Once you've taken the time to reflect and seek support, it can be helpful to create a concrete plan for moving forward. [Question]
i tried to od on tylenol and took like 0 pill ended up tripping ball then throwing up and being miserable for the rest of the night now i have some sort of phobia in which i can not even think about taking pill without getting extremely nauseous anyone know how to overcome this new fear is there a better subreddit to ask this question

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a difficult experience with Tylenol, and I can understand how challenging it must have been for you. It's important to prioritize your well-being and take steps towards overcoming this fear.

One suggestion could be to gradually expose yourself to the thought or idea of taking a pill. Start by simply thinking about it without any negative emotions attached. If you feel comfortable, try writing down the thought or saying it out loud. This process can help desensitize your mind to the fear associated with taking pills.

Additionally, it might be helpful to explore alternative methods of managing pain or discomfort. There are various natural remedies and techniques that you can try, such as applying heat or cold packs, practicing relaxation exercises, or trying herbal supplements. Experimenting with different options can help you find what works best for you.

Finding support from others who have similar experiences can also be beneficial. Consider joining support groups or online communities where you can share your concerns and learn from others who have overcome similar fears. These spaces can provide validation, guidance, and practical tips for managing your phobia.

Remember, overcoming fears takes time and patience. Celebrate small victories along the way and be kind to yourself throughout the process. If you continue to struggle with this fear, it may be helpful to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.

As for a subreddit, there are several communities where individuals discuss phobias and share their experiences. You could try searching for "phobia" or "fear" in r/mentalhealth or r/phobias to see if there are any relevant discussions happening. However, keep in mind that online communities can vary in quality and accuracy, so it's always a good idea to verify information and seek professional advice if needed.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been going through a difficult time lately. It's understandable that starting a new job and leaving a toxic workplace would bring about mixed emotions. It's not uncommon to feel a sense of uncertainty or discomfort during such significant changes in life.

Firstly, it might be helpful to acknowledge and validate your feelings. It's okay to feel chaotic or out of place, even if everything appears objectively fine. Emotions can sometimes be more complex than what meets the eye.

Consider exploring different aspects of your life that may contribute to these feelings. Reflect on whether there are any underlying stressors or unresolved issues that could be impacting your sense of control and groundedness. Sometimes, we may not immediately recognize the sources of our emotional distress, but taking the time to reflect can provide valuable insights.

Additionally, it's important to remember that finding a solution to these feelings might not always be straightforward. Sometimes, we simply need to allow ourselves to experience and process our emotions without immediately seeking external solutions. Journaling or engaging in creative outlets like art or music can also help in understanding and expressing your emotions.

In terms of feeling at home or grounded, consider spending quality time with loved ones or engaging in activities that bring you joy and comfort. Surrounding yourself with supportive individuals and participating in hobbies that align with your interests can foster a sense of belonging and stability.

Remember, you are not a "stupid piece of shit" deserving of punishment. Mistakes happen, and it's important to learn from them. Additionally, take some time to reflect on your own behavior and consider if there are any underlying reasons why you might have made those advances. Regarding your friendship, it's important to have an open and honest conversation with your friend. Express your desire to salvage the friendship and emphasize that you want to rebuild trust. hey i posted a question here a while ago but no one answered i don t know if maybe my question got private it or something i don t think it broke any rule it s just that i m afraid death will leave you conciouss until you decompose or get cremated or that you ll suffocate due to not breathing do we know that being dead mean you re definitely unconscious

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling concerned about your question not being answered. It can be frustrating when we feel like our inquiries are being overlooked. I'm here to provide some guidance and reassurance.

Firstly, it's important to note that questions posted on this platform are generally visible to others, unless they are marked as private. Therefore, it's unlikely that your question was automatically set to private. However, it's possible that the volume of questions or other factors may have contributed to it not being addressed yet.

Regarding your concerns about death and consciousness, it's a valid topic to explore. When we die, our bodies undergo physical changes that lead to the cessation of life functions. This includes the eventual loss of consciousness. Most people believe that once we are clinically dead, we are no longer aware or able to experience anything.

As for suffocating due to not breathing, it's important to understand that our bodies have natural mechanisms in place to maintain oxygen levels during the process of dying. The process of expiration slows down significantly as our body prepares for the end of life. Additionally, medical professionals often take steps to ensure that the individual's airway remains open during this time.

While I can't provide a definitive answer about what happens after we die, it's worth noting that many cultures and belief systems have their own interpretations and explanations. Some people find comfort in spiritual or religious beliefs surrounding death, while others may seek solace in scientific explanations or philosophical discussions.

If you find yourself struggling with anxiety or fear related to these concerns, it might be helpful to explore coping strategies such as mindfulness exercises, deep breathing techniques, or engaging in activities that bring you joy and peace. Talking to trusted friends or loved ones about your feelings can also provide support.

Remember, everyone's experience with death is unique, and there is no one-size-fits-all answer. If you continue to feel overwhelmed or distressed by these thoughts, it could be beneficial to reach out to a mental health professional who can offer personalized guidance and support.

 It can be incredibly challenging to navigate through depression, especially when it feels like it's affecting your overall well-being. It's important to remember that everyone's journey with depression is unique, and there is no one-size-fits-all answer to whether someone has gotten over it for good or if it will continue to impact you.

One thing that may be helpful is to focus on self-care and finding activities that bring you joy and provide a sense of fulfillment. Engaging in hobbies or interests that you used to enjoy, even if you don't feel motivated at first, can sometimes help lift your mood and provide a temporary relief from the heaviness of depression.

Additionally, reaching out for support can make a significant difference. Talking to trusted friends or family members about what you're going through can provide a sense of understanding and validation. Sometimes, simply sharing your thoughts and feelings with someone who cares can alleviate some of the emotional burden you may be carrying.

While vacationing on a tropical island might seem like a dream come true, it's important to acknowledge that external factors alone may not be enough to completely overcome depression. It might be beneficial to consider seeking professional help from a mental health expert who can provide guidance tailored specifically to your needs. They can assist you in developing coping strategies, exploring underlying causes of your depression, and working towards long-term healing.

Remember, healing takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories along the way. You deserve support and care as you navigate through this challenging period in your life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i have been suffering from an eating disorder anorexia anorexia nervosa since i wa yo i m in my early 0 now about a month ago i had an issue with my chinese takeout that heighten not only my ed but my anxiety level too i constantly fear that everything i eat will cause stomach ache or make me sick so i m cautious to eat anything anymore i have slowly been on the road to recovery with my ed so this made me take step back rather than moving forward it ha also caused me to lose sleep at night and when i do end up sleeping i wake up with awful anxiety my anxiety ha been overwhelming because a day doe not go by where i m not excessively panicking i can t even go out of my house without breaking down it is so bad that i only ever feel safe in my own room i feel like i m trapped in this on going cycle with no kind of exit i am desperate to find a solution to my problem but therapy ha not worked for me nor medication i have no idea what i need to do to better my food anxiety and general anxiety i do my absolute best to not think about it all of my issue but it s so damn hard when my body say otherwise ha anyone suffered from this did you find anything that helped alleviate your anxiety or ed any helpful advice is welcome

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and frustrated with your eating disorder and anxiety. It takes a lot of strength to reach out for support, so I commend you for doing that.

Firstly, it's important to remember that everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some general strategies that might be helpful in managing anxiety and improving your relationship with food.

One approach could be gradually exposing yourself to situations that trigger anxiety around food. Start small and gradually increase the level of exposure over time. For example, you could begin by ordering food at a restaurant and then progress to eating in front of others. This can help desensitize your anxiety response and build confidence in your ability to manage those feelings.

Another strategy is to focus on self-care and relaxation techniques. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and help you relax can be beneficial. This could include things like practicing mindfulness or deep breathing exercises, engaging in hobbies or creative outlets, or spending time in nature.

Additionally, seeking support from loved ones can make a significant difference. Opening up to someone you trust about what you're going through can provide emotional support and understanding. They may also be able to offer practical assistance, such as helping with meal planning or accompanying you to appointments.

Lastly, consider reaching out to a healthcare professional who specializes in eating disorders. They can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They may suggest therapy options such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), which have been effective in helping individuals overcome anxiety and manage their eating disorders.

Remember, recovery takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories. You deserve support and healing, and I believe in your ability to find a solution that works for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i am having some severe anxiety attack these can last for hour my blood pressure and heart rate get very high i ve been to the er but they just gave me ativan and it doesn t help i have trouble breathing it s hard to talk my limb go numb my heart feel cold i have severe urge to vomit and go to the bathroom

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now with your anxiety attacks. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to help manage your symptoms.

Firstly, it might be helpful to try deep breathing exercises when you feel an anxiety attack coming on. Taking slow, deep breaths can help regulate your heart rate and bring your body back into balance. You can try inhaling deeply through your nose for a count of four, holding your breath for a count of four, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth for a count of six. Repeat this several times until you start to feel more calm and centered.

Additionally, finding activities that help you relax and distract from the anxiety can be beneficial. Engaging in hobbies or spending time doing things you enjoy can provide a sense of relief and divert your attention away from the anxiety. Whether it's reading a book, listening to music, taking a walk in nature, or practicing mindfulness, finding what works best for you can make a significant difference.

In terms of managing your physical symptoms, it may be worth exploring different techniques such as progressive muscle relaxation or guided imagery. These practices can help reduce muscle tension and promote a sense of relaxation throughout your body.

When it comes to your difficulty breathing, focusing on your breath can help regulate your respiratory pattern. Try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose, filling up your belly with air, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth. Paying attention to your breath can help calm your nervous system and alleviate some of the discomfort.

Lastly, it's important to establish a support system around you. Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can offer emotional support during difficult times. Sometimes just having someone to talk to can provide a sense of relief and comfort.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. If your symptoms persist or worsen, it's important to consult with a healthcare professional who can provide further guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really tough when you're feeling overwhelmed and it seems like everything is going wrong. It's completely understandable that you would want a break from all of this. Losing a close friend can be incredibly difficult, especially when it leaves you feeling alone again.

One suggestion I have is to try reaching out to others for support. Sometimes talking to someone who cares about us can provide a sense of relief and comfort. Consider reaching out to family members, other friends, or even joining support groups where you can connect with people who may be going through similar experiences.

Additionally, finding healthy outlets for your emotions can be beneficial. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and help you relax can provide a much-needed break from the overwhelming feelings. This could include things like exercising, practicing mindfulness or meditation, pursuing hobbies, or spending time in nature.

Taking care of yourself physically can also make a difference. Ensuring you're getting enough sleep, eating well, and engaging in regular exercise can positively impact your mental well-being. Sometimes, small changes in our daily routine can have a big impact on how we feel overall.

Lastly, it might be helpful to explore any underlying thoughts or beliefs that contribute to your feelings of being overwhelmed. Journaling can be a useful tool for self-reflection and gaining insight into patterns of thinking that may be perpetuating your current emotional state.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient with yourself as you navigate through this challenging time, and don't hesitate to seek professional help if needed.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really challenging to experience such intense feelings of anxiety and difficulty breathing. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, but there are some suggestions that may help you manage these symptoms.

Firstly, focusing on your breath can be helpful. When you notice yourself feeling anxious or struggling to breathe, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. This can help regulate your breathing and bring a sense of calmness.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms to distract yourself from anxious thoughts can be beneficial. Engaging in activities that you enjoy and find relaxing, such as reading, listening to music, or going for a walk, can help shift your focus away from anxious thoughts and provide a sense of relief.

It might also be helpful to identify any triggers or patterns that seem to contribute to your anxiety. Keeping a journal where you record your thoughts, feelings, and situations that trigger anxiety can provide valuable insights. By identifying these triggers, you can work towards avoiding or managing them more effectively.

Lastly, consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member for support. Talking about your feelings with someone who cares about you can provide comfort and reassurance. If your symptoms persist or worsen, it could be helpful to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.

Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself during this process. Managing anxiety takes time and effort, but with the right strategies and support, it is possible to find relief and improve your well-being.

and i don t think i ever will i lost my boyfriend and my life s worth of item at the same time living back at home ha been difficult a my sister life here and we do not have the best relationship she is severely mentally ill with addiction depression and borderline personality disorder so it s been very hard trying to manage her mood outburst destruction etc she ha attacked me many time said countless hurtful thing and done endless physical damage to the house living with her is very stressful on top of all this my grandpa just died tonight i got a call from my brother out of the blue i can t process this right now and i m at my wit end in the past month i ve lost my boyfriend whom i still love my old apartment and old life in oregon all of my life s worth of belonging and now my grandpa it s almost funny how insanely negative this year ha been i simply can not see myself recovering from all this loss and sadness and i don t know what to do it is just too much and i have no hope or light left i m feeling suicidal

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a lot this year, and I can understand why you're feeling overwhelmed and hopeless. It's important to remember that you don't have to go through this alone.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge the pain and loss you've experienced. Losing a significant other, your belongings, and your old life can be incredibly difficult to cope with. It's completely normal to feel like you're at your wit's end after going through so much in such a short period of time.

Finding a new therapist can be a challenging process, especially when you've had to move to a different state. However, there are resources available to help you in your search. You could start by reaching out to mental health organizations or helplines in your area to see if they have any recommendations for therapists who may be able to provide remote or teletherapy services. This way, you can still receive support without being physically present in the same location as your therapist.

In addition to seeking professional help, it might also be beneficial to reach out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support during this difficult time. Sometimes, simply talking about our feelings and concerns with someone who cares can make a significant difference in how we feel.

It's understandable that living with your sister is challenging due to her mental illness and addiction. While it may not be easy, it could be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with her about how her actions and behaviors are affecting you. Setting boundaries and expressing your needs can contribute to creating a healthier environment for both of you.

Lastly, grieving the loss of your grandpa is a natural part of the healing process. Allow yourself to feel the emotions that come up, and consider finding healthy outlets for expressing those emotions, such as journaling or engaging in creative activities.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient and kind to yourself throughout this journey. If you ever feel overwhelmed or find yourself in immediate danger, don't hesitate to reach out to a helpline or emergency services. You deserve support and care, and there are people who genuinely want to help you navigate through these difficult times.

 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now. It's understandable that living in a noisy environment and dealing with depression can be incredibly challenging. Firstly, it might be helpful to reach out to your apartment management and express your concerns about the drilling noise. They may be able to provide some assistance or solutions to help alleviate the distractions while you try to sleep. Additionally, consider creating a relaxing bedtime routine to help calm your mind before going to sleep. This could include activities such as reading a book, taking a warm bath, or practicing deep breathing exercises.

Regarding your feelings about school, it's common to question the reasons for being there. However, attending school can also offer opportunities for personal growth and career advancement. If you're feeling overwhelmed, it might be beneficial to speak with your academic advisor or professor about your concerns. They can provide guidance and support to help you navigate through these challenges.

When it comes to your job experiences, it's important to remember that not every workplace is the same. Consider exploring different job options and networking with professionals in your field. Building connections and seeking advice from those who have been successful in their careers can be invaluable.

In terms of your emotional state, it's essential to prioritize self-care. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help boost your mood and overall well-being. Whether it's spending time outdoors, pursuing hobbies, or connecting with loved ones, finding moments of happiness can make a significant difference.

Lastly, reaching out to a mental health professional can provide you with additional support and guidance tailored to your specific needs. They can assist you in developing coping strategies, exploring underlying issues, and working towards a more fulfilling life.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it may take time to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and continue to seek out resources and support that can help you navigate through these challenges.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge the strength and resilience it takes to reach out for support. You're not alone in this journey, even though it may sometimes feel like it. There are people who care about your well-being and want to help.

One suggestion I have is to consider reaching out to a healthcare professional who can provide guidance specific to your situation. It's natural to feel guilty when we perceive ourselves as having more privileges than others, but it's essential to recognize that everyone's circumstances are unique. Be kind to yourself and try to practice self-compassion.

When it comes to your work situation, it might be helpful to have an open conversation with your employer about your health challenges. They may be able to provide accommodations or explore alternative solutions that could allow you to continue working while managing your health.

Lastly, while I'm not a mental health expert, finding ways to cope with stress and anxiety can be beneficial. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies or spending time in nature, can help improve your overall well-being. Additionally, reaching out to supportive friends or loved ones can provide comfort during difficult times.

Remember, you deserve support and care. Taking small steps towards seeking help and exploring different options can make a significant difference in your journey towards better health and well-being.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a lot of distress and anxiety lately, particularly when it comes to existential thoughts and the fear of facing unknown or scary situations. It's understandable that this can be overwhelming and exhausting for you.

One suggestion I have is to try practicing mindfulness techniques. Mindfulness involves focusing on the present moment and accepting your thoughts and feelings without judgment. By doing this, you may find it easier to let go of anxious thoughts and bring yourself back to the present. There are many resources available online, such as guided meditation apps or videos, that can help you learn and practice mindfulness.

Another strategy that might be helpful is creating a routine or structure in your daily life. Having a predictable schedule can provide a sense of stability and security, which can help alleviate some of the anxiety you're experiencing. Try to incorporate activities that bring you joy and relaxation into your routine, whether it's engaging in hobbies, spending time with loved ones, or simply taking breaks to do something you enjoy.

Additionally, reaching out to supportive friends or family members can make a big difference. Sometimes just talking about what you're going through with someone who cares can provide relief and perspective. Lastly, it might be beneficial to explore professional help if you haven't already done so. Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it's important to be patient and kind to yourself throughout this process. You deserve happiness and peace, and with time and effort, it's possible to find them again.

[Question]
on the surface i can think of a lot of reason feeling ashamed about needing med worrying about side effect forgetting about them etc but at the end of the day i can t say exactly why i just know i don t want to take my med at the same time i know i need them i know that without them i simple task like showering and doing dish feel impossible i ll fall behind on my schoolwork isolated myself and sleep hour a day i know they work for me and that i ve felt much better when i wa taking them regularly but dang it i just don t want to take them one day i just ignored my alarm to take them and then i ve kept doing it now i take them so sporadically that they can t be doing much they re an ssri and mood stabilizer so they need to build up in your system and such part of me think maybe i just hate the daily reminder that i m not ok like i think that maybe if i ignore it for long enough i ll forget that i feel that way but even knowing that may be a part of it it doesn t feel like that s all there is to it and i don t know what to do about it mostly i m just wondering if anyone else feel like this too and if you do do you know why you feel that way and what may have helped you get back on track with taking them regularly i ve talked to my therapist and friend but i haven t been able to really figure out the full reason i feel this way or how to get back to taking them regularly if you ve dealt with this before or think you may understand why this resistance to taking med is happening i d appreciate hearing some potential reason or way to improve this of course everyone s mental health is unique so i may not relate to someone else s reason but i would still really appreciate hearing any potential one so i can understand my feeling about this a bit better

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be challenging when you're experiencing resistance towards taking your medication, especially when you know it's beneficial for your mental health. It's important to remember that everyone's experience is unique, but there are some potential reasons why this might be happening.

One possible reason could be related to the daily reminder that you're not feeling okay. Sometimes, people may resist taking their medication because they associate it with feeling better or not feeling as bad. However, it's important to remember that medication is not a cure-all, but rather a tool to help manage symptoms. Taking your medication consistently can help build up in your system and provide consistent support for your mental health.

Another possible reason could be related to forgetfulness or lack of motivation. It's common to forget or struggle with motivation when it comes to taking care of ourselves. One strategy that might help is creating a routine or schedule that includes medication reminders. Setting an alarm or having a specific time each day dedicated to taking your medication can make it easier to stay on track. Additionally, finding ways to motivate yourself, such as rewarding yourself for taking your medication or engaging in activities that bring you joy, can also be helpful.

It's also worth considering if there are any underlying emotional or stressful factors contributing to this resistance. Sometimes, stress or negative emotions can interfere with our ability to follow through with self-care tasks like taking medication. If you notice that your resistance is correlated with certain emotions or stressors, it might be helpful to explore coping strategies or seek additional support to address those underlying issues.

Remember, it's important to communicate openly with your therapist or healthcare provider about your concerns and feelings surrounding your medication. They can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific situation. Additionally, reaching out to support groups or online communities where individuals share similar experiences can offer valuable insights and encouragement.

Ultimately, finding what works best for you may involve some trial and error. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. With time and persistence, you can work towards improving your medication adherence and regaining a sense of stability and well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i now think about suicide constantly i feel like it is my only option in the long term i will never finish school and be able to hold down a job i will never be able to be stable enough to give my wife child i can t live up to anything anyone expects of me i am stuck though my death would be a catastrophe in my wife s life and my brother s life and i have a few friend who would be devastated a well also and i really hate to say this but the biggest reason i can t is because i can t leave my dog with anyone else he is very attached to me and no one else and would be very unhappy without me so i am stuck i can t function despite 0 year of trying medication and therapy i have no will to live except not to hurt people around me i hate this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's really tough to hear that you're feeling this way and it sounds like you're going through a difficult time. It's important to remember that you don't have to face this alone, and there are people who can support you.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge the pain and frustration you're experiencing. It's understandable that you feel trapped and like suicide is your only option. However, it's important to know that there are other possibilities and alternatives that can help you navigate through this challenging period.

One step you could consider taking is reaching out to a helpline or crisis hotline. They can provide immediate support and guidance when you're feeling overwhelmed. Additionally, connecting with a trusted friend or family member who can offer a listening ear might also be helpful. Sometimes just talking about our feelings can bring some relief.

In terms of your education and employment, it's important to remember that setbacks happen to everyone at some point. Instead of focusing on what you haven't achieved yet, try to break things down into smaller, achievable goals. For example, setting aside specific times each day or week to study or search for job opportunities can make a big difference over time.

Regarding your concerns about being stable enough to have children, it's important to recognize that there are many factors involved in starting a family. While it may feel daunting, it's not solely determined by your current circumstances. Exploring resources such as parenting classes or counseling services could provide valuable information and support as you consider this aspect of your life.

When it comes to leaving your dog behind, it's understandable that you're worried about how he would cope without you. However, there are often options available for pet care, such as trusted friends, family members, or even professional pet sitters who can provide temporary care for your dog. Exploring these possibilities might alleviate some of the guilt and anxiety you're experiencing.

While medication and therapy haven't been effective so far, it's important to keep in mind that everyone's journey is unique. It might be worth exploring different therapists or treatment options until you find one that resonates with you. Additionally, engaging in self-care activities that bring you joy and relaxation can help improve your overall well-being.

Lastly, I want to emphasize that reaching out for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. If you ever feel like you need immediate assistance, please don't hesitate to contact a helpline or crisis hotline. Remember, there are people who care about you and want to support you through this difficult time.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It's important to acknowledge that combining benzodiazepines and alcohol can indeed have dangerous effects on your mental and physical health. Regarding your anxiety, it's understandable that you may feel concerned about the potential damage caused by combining these substances. However, it's essential to remember that your brain is resilient and has the ability to recover from such experiences. It's important not to jump to conclusions and assume that you've irreversibly damaged your brain chemistry.

Anxiety can be challenging, but there are steps you can take to manage it effectively. Additionally, engaging in self-care activities such as exercise, getting enough sleep, maintaining a balanced diet, and practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation can also contribute to reducing anxiety levels. These strategies can promote overall well-being and improve your ability to cope with stress.

If your anxiety persists or worsens, it might be beneficial to consult with a healthcare professional who can provide further guidance tailored to your specific needs. They can evaluate your situation more comprehensively and suggest appropriate interventions, such as therapy or medication if necessary.

Remember, recovery is possible, and you deserve support and healing. By taking proactive steps towards managing your anxiety and seeking professional help when needed, you can work towards regaining control over your well-being.

so i wa just working a completely normal day in fact i felt pretty good i work at a goodwill so it s relatively social but i can handle it cause honestly every person that enters that store is fantastically polite and friendly but for some reason half way through my shift i begin getting light head i assumed it wa my tight hat or my new prescription glass so i took those off and got back to work and for a little bit actually helped but it got worse and worse my hand were shaky and i wa super light headed bless my coworkers cause i mentioned i wasn t feeling great and my manager let me have a break despite not requiring one due to shirt shift one of my coworkers actually spent a dollar to get me a snack and i wa improving i didn t wan na leave these lovely people short staffed a i wa the only product handler closing so i tried getting back on the floor and instantly i wa back in it and again bless my manager cause she suggested it wa fine and i could go home i got in my car and instantly my face felt numb by the time i wa home a relatively short drive my chest wa super numb too im i ve only ever had this feeling once before and i wa wondering if this is what a standard panic attack feel like how do i bring this up with my dad in order to get this figured out sorry if this wa long it actually helped a good bit in getting me relaxed just writing this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you had a really challenging experience at work today. It's great that you were able to recognize the symptoms and take steps to address them. It can be really helpful to remove any potential triggers, like tight clothing or new glasses, when you notice these feelings coming on.

When it comes to discussing this with your dad, it might be beneficial to approach the conversation from a place of curiosity rather than assuming he knows what's going on. You could try saying something like, "Hey dad, I wanted to talk to you about something that happened today. I've noticed that I've been experiencing some really strange symptoms at work, like feeling lightheaded and having shaky hands. I was wondering if you have any ideas what could be causing it?"

By framing it as a question, you're giving your dad an opportunity to share his thoughts without feeling pressured or accused. This can create a more open and supportive environment for both of you. Additionally, mentioning that you're curious and looking for answers together can help build a sense of teamwork and collaboration.

Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process. It may take some time to figure out what's causing these symptoms, but by staying open-minded and seeking support, you're already taking positive steps towards understanding and managing them.

i hate it i barely sleep on my weekend off day have to wake up early for work and i still feel tired usually everyday when i wake up for work i automatically have to go to the bathroom must be my anxiety because my off day i don t my work is great and i work by myself and see basically no one all 0 hour but still i won t be at home lol

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really challenging when you're not getting enough sleep on your weekend off day and it's affecting your overall energy levels. It sounds like you're experiencing some anxiety related to going to the bathroom in the morning, which may be contributing to your tiredness.

One suggestion I have is to try establishing a consistent sleep routine. Going to bed and waking up at the same time every day, even on weekends, can help regulate your body's internal clock and improve the quality of your sleep. Additionally, creating a relaxing bedtime routine, such as reading a book or taking a warm bath, can signal to your body that it's time to wind down and prepare for sleep.

Another strategy that might be helpful is practicing relaxation techniques before bed. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery can all help reduce anxiety and promote better sleep. You could try incorporating these techniques into your evening routine to help calm your mind and body before bedtime.

In terms of your anxiety around going to the bathroom in the morning, it might be beneficial to explore any underlying thoughts or beliefs that are contributing to this anxiety. Sometimes our minds can create unnecessary worries or fears, and identifying and challenging those thoughts can help alleviate anxiety symptoms. Writing down your thoughts and examining their validity can be a helpful starting point.

Lastly, finding ways to manage stress throughout the day can also contribute to better sleep and overall well-being. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies or spending time with loved ones, can provide a much-needed break from work-related stress.

Remember, everyone's experience is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. If these suggestions don't seem to improve your sleep patterns and anxiety, it could be beneficial to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.
