[Question]
so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've had an epiphany about how your stutter has been affecting you and how it's important to see yourself as more than just your stutter. It takes a lot of self-awareness and courage to make this realization.

Owning your stutter can be a gradual process, but here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Practice self-acceptance: Start by accepting yourself as you are, including your stutter. Remind yourself that your stutter is just one aspect of who you are, and it doesn't define your worth or capabilities.

2. Challenge negative thoughts: Notice any negative thoughts or beliefs you may have about your stutter, and try to replace them with more positive and realistic ones. For example, instead of thinking "people will judge me," remind yourself that most people are not even aware of your stutter or find it interesting.

3. Build confidence through practice: Work on speaking in situations where you feel comfortable, such as with close friends or family members. Gradually increase the difficulty level by speaking in front of larger groups or engaging in public speaking opportunities. The more you practice, the more confident you'll become.

4. Seek support: Consider finding a support group or community where you can connect with others who have similar experiences. Sharing your journey and hearing from others who have overcome similar challenges can provide encouragement and inspiration.

5. Celebrate small victories: Acknowledge and celebrate each step forward, no matter how small it may seem. Recognize the progress you're making in owning your stutter and being proud of yourself for taking this journey.

Remember, changing deeply ingrained beliefs and behaviors takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself and don't put too much pressure on achieving immediate results. With persistence and self-compassion, you can become more confident and comfortable with your stutter.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's completely understandable that you're feeling guilty for canceling your classes, especially since you had a week off recently. However, it's important to prioritize your own well-being and take care of yourself when you're not feeling well. Your body needs rest and recovery during periods like this, and it's okay to give yourself permission to take a sick day if needed.

When it comes to managing anxiety, there are a few strategies you can try. Firstly, practicing deep breathing exercises can help calm your mind and body. Taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth can activate the body's relaxation response and reduce anxiety.

Another technique you might find helpful is grounding yourself in the present moment. This involves focusing on your senses and bringing your attention to what you can see, hear, touch, taste, and smell in your immediate surroundings. By redirecting your focus away from anxious thoughts and into the present moment, you can help alleviate some of the anxiety.

Additionally, engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can be beneficial. Whether it's listening to music, going for a walk in nature, or spending time with loved ones, finding moments of happiness and peace can help counteract the negative effects of anxiety.

Remember, it's important to communicate with your students and colleagues about your situation. Letting them know in advance if possible, and providing alternative arrangements or assignments can help minimize any inconvenience caused by your absence.

Lastly, don't underestimate the power of self-care. Taking care of yourself physically, emotionally, and mentally is crucial for managing anxiety. Make sure you're getting enough rest, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that promote overall well-being.

I hope these suggestions help you navigate through this challenging time. Remember, it's okay to prioritize your own health and well-being. You deserve to take care of yourself, and I believe in your ability to bounce back from this.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

so i ve struggled w executive dysfunction for 9 year throughout my year of college there wa not one assignment that i did not do the night before it wa due i studied late ate terribly amp went thru a terrible depression a year after graduating i still have a really hard time doing thing in general i stall before i do anything at all amp it oftentimes lead to me not doing the thing at all also i kind of live my entire life on pause only taking care of myself when i have something planned or to look forward to i left my job that i wa insanely good at bc the commitment amp longevity terrified me why can t i function amp what ha helped u work thru these feeling

One approach you could try is breaking down tasks into smaller, more manageable steps. This can make them feel less overwhelming and easier to tackle. Prioritizing tasks based on their importance and deadline can also be helpful in staying organized and focused.

Creating a routine or schedule might be beneficial for you. Having a structured plan can provide a sense of stability and purpose, which can be particularly helpful when dealing with executive dysfunction. Try to set specific times for different activities, including self-care, work, and leisure.

Additionally, practicing good self-care is crucial. Taking care of your physical and mental well-being can have a positive impact on your overall functioning. Regular exercise, healthy eating, and getting enough sleep can all contribute to improved cognitive function and mood.

Finding support from loved ones or joining a support group where you can connect with others who may have similar experiences can also be valuable. Sharing your struggles and successes with others who understand can provide validation and encouragement.

Lastly, consider seeking professional guidance from a therapist or counselor who specializes in executive dysfunction. They can work with you to develop personalized coping strategies and provide additional support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, it's okay to take things one step at a time and be patient with yourself. You deserve compassion and understanding as you navigate through these challenges.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Starting a new job can definitely be nerve-wracking, especially when it involves a significant change from what you've been doing. It's completely normal to feel anxious about this transition, but I want you to know that you're not alone in feeling this way.

First of all, it's great that you've taken your time to overcome your anxiety and have been gradually pushing yourself towards this new chapter. That shows a lot of strength and determination. Remember to be proud of yourself for all that you've accomplished so far.

Regarding your concerns about the job, it's important to keep in mind that learning new skills takes time and patience. You mentioned that you won't be able to start bathing dogs until you learn from the other groomer, which is a smart approach. Take it one step at a time, and don't put too much pressure on yourself to perform perfectly right away.

As for the worry about the day going by slowly because you won't be doing anything or getting paid until you're ready to start bathing, try not to focus too much on the time. Instead, try to make the most of your time by observing and learning from the other groomer. This will help you gain the necessary skills and confidence to eventually start bathing dogs on your own.

It's great that you have a support system in place, including your family and friends who are excited for you. However, it's important to remember that this is ultimately your journey, and you should trust yourself to handle any challenges that come your way. Believe in your abilities and give yourself credit for taking this step towards your career goals.

Lastly, try to stay positive and remind yourself that making mistakes or facing uncertainties is a natural part of growth. Embrace the learning opportunities that come with this new job, and remember that every step forward is a step closer to achieving your dreams.

I hope these suggestions help ease some of your worries and anxieties. Remember, you've got this!

i ve so many health issue and i m only starting with atopic and seborrhoeic dermatitis and psoriasis through endometriosis and hypothyroidism to ibs fucked up hip and pelvic floor and that s not even all and obviously only phisical thing that are wrong and i really try to take care of all of this problem but it s exhausting and for what to live in a world where everything is getting more and more fucked up every minute the pandemic the war the famine that s probably gon na come soon a a result of the war i m polish so very much can feel the effect of what s happening in ukraine i m also vegan and knowing that so many animal are still suffering and the price of everything are going up i don t even think i can afford to live anymore and i m really trying going on a walk in the forest everyday doing yoga eating healthy just generally taking care of myself like a normal person would but i just can t see the light at the end of the tunnel rant over

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you have been dealing with a lot of health issues and it's understandable that it can be exhausting for you. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to manage your symptoms and improve your overall well-being.

Firstly, it might be helpful to focus on self-care and finding activities that bring you joy and relaxation. Engaging in regular exercise, such as going for walks in the forest, can have numerous benefits for both your physical and mental health. Additionally, practicing yoga can help reduce stress and promote a sense of calmness.

When it comes to managing your health conditions, it could be beneficial to consult with healthcare professionals who specialize in each specific area. They can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your unique needs. Keeping track of your symptoms and any changes in their severity can also help you communicate more effectively with them.

In terms of the challenges you mentioned regarding the pandemic, war, famine, and political unrest, it's understandable that these external factors can contribute to feelings of hopelessness and anxiety. However, it's important to remember that your well-being is within your control, even if external circumstances may seem overwhelming. Finding ways to stay informed without becoming consumed by negative news can help alleviate some of the stress associated with these events.

Regarding your concerns about animal suffering and rising prices, it's commendable that you want to make a positive impact on the world. However, it's important to recognize that making changes in your personal life might not directly address all the issues at hand. Instead, consider exploring ways to support animal welfare and sustainability, such as supporting organizations that advocate for animal rights or making conscious choices in your purchasing decisions.

Lastly, remember that progress takes time, and setbacks are a normal part of the journey. Celebrate small victories along the way and be kind to yourself throughout this process. You deserve compassion and support as you navigate through these challenges.

Firstly, it might be helpful to try and identify any patterns or behaviors that could be contributing to the lack of social interaction. Reflect on how you've been approaching conversations and interactions with others. Are there any specific topics or questions you could ask to engage people? Sometimes, people may not realize they're being overlooked or ignored, so opening up the conversation with something specific about their interests or experiences might help them feel more comfortable around you.

Additionally, finding common interests or joining clubs or groups related to your hobbies can provide an opportunity to meet like-minded individuals. Engaging in activities you enjoy can also boost your mood and overall well-being, making it easier to connect with others naturally.

While making new friends might seem daunting, it's important to keep trying. Don't be too hard on yourself if things don't happen overnight. hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a lot, and I can understand how challenging it must be for you. Dealing with anxiety disorder can be difficult, especially when faced with significant life events such as the passing of loved ones.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some general strategies that might help you manage your anxiety in the moment. One technique you could try is deep breathing exercises. Taking slow, deep breaths can help activate your body's relaxation response and reduce feelings of anxiety.

Another suggestion is to engage in activities that bring you joy or provide a sense of calm. This could include things like listening to music, going for a walk in nature, practicing mindfulness or meditation, or engaging in creative outlets such as painting or writing. These activities can help redirect your focus away from anxious thoughts and bring you back to the present moment.

Additionally, it might be helpful to establish a routine that includes self-care practices. This could involve getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and incorporating regular exercise into your daily routine. Taking care of your physical health can have a positive impact on your mental well-being.

Lastly, reaching out to supportive friends or family members can make a big difference. Sometimes just talking about your feelings with someone who cares can provide a sense of relief. If you feel comfortable, consider sharing what you're going through with someone you trust.

Remember, it's important to be patient and kind to yourself during this process. Healing takes time, and it's okay to have ups and downs along the way. You deserve support and understanding as you navigate through these challenges.

i have been away from home for week and yesterday i wa scheduled to return my friend had offered to pick me up from the airport for context i don t live in the safest city for woman after i land my friend text me saying they can t pick me up from the airport and i should book a cab and come home i wa at the airport from pm to am because there were no cab available creepy men started following me stating oh no one s here to pick you up i had to go to the police because the men didn t stop following me i had a breakdown in public and i couldn t breathe i finally called a friend who life near by who came to pick me up at around 0 am by then i wa completely wrecked yesterday wa a complete mess and im still feeling anxious and triggered

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you had a really difficult experience while traveling and returning home. It's understandable that you're feeling anxious and triggered after what happened to you. Here are some suggestions to help you cope with your feelings:

1. Take care of yourself: Make sure to prioritize self-care and relaxation. Engage in activities that bring you joy and help you unwind. This could include things like taking a warm bath, practicing deep breathing exercises, or engaging in a hobby you enjoy.

2. Reach out for support: It's important to lean on your support system during times like these. Consider talking to someone you trust about what happened, such as a close friend or family member. Sharing your feelings and experiences can provide relief and validation.

3. Establish a safety plan: Create a personal safety plan to ensure your well-being. This could involve identifying safe spaces or people you can reach out to in emergencies. Additionally, consider learning self-defense techniques or carrying a personal safety device if you feel comfortable doing so.

4. Practice grounding techniques: When you feel overwhelmed or triggered, grounding techniques can help bring you back to the present moment. Focus on your senses by noticing five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This exercise can help anchor you in reality and reduce anxiety.

5. Seek professional help if needed: If you continue to struggle with anxiety, triggers, or flashbacks, it may be beneficial to seek professional help from a mental health therapist. They can provide additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient and kind to yourself throughout the process. You deserve support and care as you navigate through this challenging experience.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
im and mo postpartum i don t know if i have ppocd but the intrusive thought are becoming unbearable my baby is healthy and for the most part happy a lot of the time i feel like a shitty mom because i work full time while my boyfriend is at home with the baby and when i get home im too exhausted to clean house or play with my baby i carry so much guilt about other people watching my son on my day off so i can get thing done because i m his mom and i should be able to take care of him and everything else myself tonight he wa losing his sh t bc he wa overtired his screaming made me feel like i wanted to hurt him or myself i would never hurt him but the thought get so loud i can t seem to escape them i wa in a psych hospital last month but it didn t help at all these thought are a constant sometimes i feel like having a baby wa the wrong choice and i ruined my life and the only way to fix my issue is to end it i just feel so alone

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and experiencing intrusive thoughts. It can be challenging to balance work, caregiving, and personal well-being, especially after having a baby. Remember that you are not alone in this journey.

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that postpartum symptoms can vary from person to person, and it may take time to determine if you have postpartum obsessive-compulsive disorder (PP-OCD). However, there are some strategies you can try to manage these intrusive thoughts.

One approach is to practice mindfulness techniques. Mindfulness involves focusing on the present moment without judgment. This can help redirect your attention away from intrusive thoughts and bring you back to the present reality. You might consider incorporating activities like deep breathing exercises, meditation, or yoga into your daily routine.

Additionally, finding healthy outlets for stress and emotions can be beneficial. Engaging in regular physical exercise, such as walking or jogging, can help release tension and improve mood. Journaling or talking to a trusted friend or family member about your feelings can also provide a sense of relief.

When it comes to guilt, remember that taking care of yourself is essential for both your well-being and your ability to care for your child. It's important to set boundaries and recognize that asking for support is not a sign of weakness but rather a strength. Consider discussing your concerns with your partner or loved ones, so they can assist with childcare responsibilities and share the load.

Regarding the thoughts of ending your life or harming your child, it's crucial to seek immediate professional help. Reach out to a mental health hotline or crisis helpline in your area. They can provide you with the necessary support and resources to ensure your safety and the well-being of your child.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient with yourself throughout this process. You deserve support and understanding as you navigate through these challenges.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're really struggling with your anxiety and it's impacting various aspects of your life, including your relationship with your family and parents. It can be incredibly frustrating and overwhelming when anxiety takes over and affects our ability to do things we want or need to do.

One suggestion I have is to try gradually exposing yourself to situations that make you anxious. For example, instead of sitting all the way in the back at the haircut place, you could start by sitting towards the middle and gradually work your way towards sitting closer to the front as you become more comfortable. This approach allows you to take small steps towards facing your fears and builds up your confidence over time.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms to manage your anxiety can be helpful. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness techniques can provide some relief during moments of heightened anxiety. You might also consider exploring activities that bring you joy and help distract your mind from anxious thoughts.

Building a support system can also be beneficial. Talking to someone you trust about what you're going through can provide emotional support and understanding. They may even offer suggestions or insights based on their own experiences.

Lastly, self-care is crucial when dealing with anxiety. Make sure you're getting enough rest, eating well, and engaging in activities that promote relaxation and stress reduction. Taking care of your overall well-being can positively impact your mental health.

Remember, everyone's journey with anxiety is unique, so it's important to find strategies that work best for you. If you continue to struggle with managing your anxiety, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

[Question]
sorry if this is the wrong subreddit for a long time in my life all i wanted wa to have someone to be there for me a person that could love me back a much i love them back but now that i have it i don t know if it s what i wanted in my past i had suicidal friend that influenced a huge part of my life i begin to realize how stupid living wa and started to question why we live i m losing all my energy slowly and slowly i find myself losing all motivation and having no goal or dream anymore this reddit is my last ditch effort on seeking help from other people i ve already started to distance from everyone around me i know that i can t be the only one that s been or going through this how were you guy able to keep your energy and have a positive outlook on life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've reached out for support, and I'm here to offer guidance. It sounds like you've been through a lot and are currently feeling lost and drained of energy. It's important to remember that everyone's experience is unique, but there are some strategies that may help you regain motivation and find a positive outlook on life.

Firstly, it might be helpful to identify any underlying causes or triggers for your current state. Reflecting on past experiences, such as the influence of your suicidal friend, can provide valuable insights into how they have impacted your perspective on life. Understanding these influences can help you gain clarity and begin to challenge any negative beliefs or thoughts that may be contributing to your current feelings.

Additionally, consider reaching out to trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support. Sometimes talking about our feelings and concerns with someone we trust can alleviate some of the burden we carry. If you feel comfortable, try opening up to them about what you're going through.

Engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can also be beneficial. Whether it's pursuing a hobby, spending time in nature, or engaging in creative outlets, finding moments of happiness and contentment can gradually replenish your energy and rekindle your passion for life.

Setting small, achievable goals for yourself can also help regain motivation. Start by identifying one thing you would like to accomplish each day or week. This could be as simple as going for a walk, completing a household chore, or reaching out to a friend. By accomplishing these goals, you'll gradually build momentum and regain a sense of purpose and accomplishment.

Lastly, practicing self-care is crucial. Make sure you're getting enough rest, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that promote relaxation and well-being. Taking care of your physical health can have a positive impact on your mental and emotional well-being.

Remember, these suggestions are not meant to replace professional help, but they can serve as starting points in your journey towards regaining motivation and finding a positive outlook on life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i am year old and i finallly came to the conclusion that i need help with anxiety i signed up for therapy and will have my first session in a couple of day prior to the therapy session i met with a prescriber to discus medication they recomended starting me off on zoloft or lexapro in general i tend to think of medication a a last resort not just for thing like this but in all aspect for example i rarely used medinces perscribed to me for pain after surgery and would only use them if absolutely necesarry i don t even like taking ibuprofen for a headache unless it is unbearable given that i am trying to figure out whether or going on anxiety medication is necessary for me or not i am worried about going on something for the rest of my life and am a little concerned about the side effect on the other hand i have been reading some post on here about how much med helped people i am hoping to hear from some people that have been on any of these medication and what their experience were also if anyone ha any thought on whether or not someone that is new to this whole anexiety improvement journey should jump into med or just try therapy first and see how that go i always kind of ignored my anxiety and told myself that since i have been able to graduate from college with a good degree hold down a great job for several year and maintain good relationship that my anxiety must not be that bad but a time go by i am starting to feel like it is getting worse and is negatively impacting my happiness and is leading my to lean on stimulant and alcohol too much which doesn t seem like a long term healthy way of handling this i have also had a couple of concussion in the last few year so i am not sure how much that play into what i am going through i would really appreciate it if some people could speak to their experience or have any encouragement or advice for someone just starting out in therapy and potentially medication please reach out if i can add additional context to my situation to help clarity where i am at also i wa reading some other post on this sub about people being tired all of the time i have spent year trying to figure out medically why to no avail i am starting to wondering if my axiety is causing it can anyone speak to any experience or epiphany they have had with this thanks garrison

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've taken the step to seek help for your anxiety, Garrison. Therapy can be a valuable tool in managing anxiety, and it's important to give it a chance before considering medication.

Starting with therapy first is often recommended because it provides an opportunity to explore the root causes of your anxiety and develop coping strategies. Therapy can also help you gain a better understanding of yourself and your emotions, which can be beneficial in making informed decisions about medication if necessary.

When it comes to medication, it's important to remember that everyone's experience is unique. While some people find relief from anxiety medication, others may not. It's essential to have an open and honest conversation with your therapist or prescriber about your concerns and preferences. They can provide guidance based on their expertise and help you weigh the pros and cons of medication.

Regarding your concerns about the side effects of medication, it's important to note that not everyone experiences the same side effects. Some common side effects of anxiety medications like Zoloft and Lexapro include nausea, dizziness, and changes in appetite. However, these side effects can vary from person to person, and your healthcare provider can discuss specifics based on your individual situation.

Additionally, it's worth considering that managing anxiety often involves a combination of approaches, including therapy, lifestyle changes, and self-care practices. Engaging in regular exercise, practicing relaxation techniques, maintaining a healthy diet, and getting enough sleep can all contribute to reducing anxiety symptoms.

Remember, this journey takes time, and it's okay to take things at your own pace. Be patient with yourself and trust the process. If you have any more questions or need further guidance, feel free to reach out.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It can be really tough to feel like nobody likes you and that your friends are making fun of you. It's important to remember that everyone's experience is unique, and just because some people may act differently doesn't mean they truly think it's cool or acceptable.

1. Consider finding a new group of friends who share similar interests or hobbies. Engaging in activities you enjoy can help meet like-minded individuals and potentially form new connections.

2. Reach out to supportive family members or trusted adults in your life. Sometimes talking to someone outside of our immediate social circle can provide a fresh perspective and emotional support.

3. Explore online communities or forums where you can connect with others who may have similar experiences. Online spaces can offer a sense of belonging and understanding that might not be present in your local community.

4. Practice self-care and self-compassion. Take time for yourself, engage in activities that bring you joy, and be kind to yourself. Remember that everyone has flaws and makes mistakes - it's part of being human.

5. If you're feeling overwhelmed or struggling to cope, consider seeking professional help from a mental health therapist or counselor. They can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, you deserve to be surrounded by people who appreciate and value you for who you are. While it may take time, keep reaching out and seeking connections that align with your values and interests.

i am so tired of having depression i hate how hard it is to get up and do the most basic thing day out of the week i don t even eat dinner because i can t get out of bed i m tired of having to put in the extra effort to hide it at work and in front of my family i ve been single for a year and a half after a year and a half long relationship but my social anxiety ha gotten so bad i can t even put myself out there i m so lonely but too afraid to make an attempt i don t think i could ever actually kill myself but i think about how much easier it would be if i wasn t alive a lot more than i used to

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling tired and frustrated with your depression. It can be really challenging to get out of bed and do even the simplest things every day. The fact that you're not eating dinner because you can't find the energy to leave the house shows how much it's affecting you.

I'm sorry to hear about your social anxiety. It must be incredibly difficult to put yourself out there after going through a long-term relationship. Loneliness can be really tough to deal with, especially when it feels like there's fear holding you back from making an attempt to connect with others.

While I'm not a professional, I can offer some suggestions that might help. Firstly, consider reaching out to a trusted friend or family member who can provide support and understanding. Sometimes just talking about what you're going through can bring some relief.

Additionally, finding small ways to take care of yourself can make a big difference. This could include engaging in activities that bring you joy or relaxation, such as hobbies or exercise. Taking care of your physical health by eating nutritious meals and getting enough sleep can also have a positive impact on your mental well-being.

It might also be helpful to explore therapy options, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or dialectical behavior therapy (DBT). These types of therapies can provide tools and strategies to manage depression and social anxiety. Online resources and helplines can guide you towards finding a therapist who specializes in these areas.

Remember, you don't have to face this alone. There are people who care and want to help. Keep reaching out and seeking support until you find what works best for you.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of distress and discomfort due to these anxiety attacks. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are steps you can take to manage and potentially reduce the frequency of these episodes.

Firstly, it might be helpful to explore any underlying thoughts or beliefs that could be contributing to your anxiety. Sometimes our minds can create scenarios or assumptions that aren't necessarily based in reality. Taking a step back and questioning these thoughts can help to challenge and reframe them.

Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can be beneficial in managing anxiety symptoms. These techniques can help to calm your body and mind during moments of heightened anxiety.

In terms of avoiding conversations that may trigger your anxiety, it's understandable that you want to minimize potential discomfort. However, it's important to remember that avoiding certain topics may also limit your ability to connect with others and form meaningful relationships. Instead, consider gradually exposing yourself to these situations and using your confidence and social skills to navigate them.

If you find that your anxiety continues to significantly impact your daily life and relationships, it may be worthwhile to seek support from a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and strategies. They can work with you to develop coping mechanisms and explore any underlying issues contributing to your anxiety.

Remember, you have the strength and resilience to overcome this challenge. With time, patience, and the right support, you can learn to manage your anxiety and regain control over your life.

i have been on prozac since maybe september last year before prozac i wa on lexapro and i wa given the highest dose of that and it worked at first and then my anxiety started up really bad again out of nowhere so i wa switched to prozac and honestly i don t feel like i ve noticed a difference especially recently i ve been getting bad anxiety attack that have worsened the past couple month i haven t had attack this bad in month it s honestly the worst ha anyone else experienced this where it feel like nothing is helping your anxiety i just want to be better my mind feel like a mental prison also doe anyone have any tip or trick that have helped calm them during an anxiety attack

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be challenging when you feel like your anxiety is not improving despite trying different medications. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some strategies that you can try to help manage your anxiety symptoms.

Firstly, it might be helpful to explore other treatment options besides medication. Therapy or counseling can provide a safe space for you to discuss your anxiety and work on coping mechanisms. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is one approach that has been found to be effective in managing anxiety. This type of therapy focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and developing healthier ways of thinking.

In addition to therapy, there are also some self-help techniques that you can try. Deep breathing exercises, such as diaphragmatic breathing or box breathing, can help calm your body and reduce anxiety during an attack. Progressive muscle relaxation is another technique where you systematically tense and relax different muscle groups to release tension in your body.

Engaging in regular physical exercise can also be beneficial for managing anxiety. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters, and helps reduce stress levels. Finding an activity that you enjoy, whether it's going for a walk, practicing yoga, or playing a sport, can make it easier to incorporate exercise into your routine.

Additionally, taking care of your overall well-being is important. This includes getting enough sleep, eating a balanced diet, and avoiding excessive caffeine or alcohol consumption. Taking breaks throughout the day to engage in activities that bring you joy and relaxation can also help alleviate anxiety symptoms.

Lastly, building a support system can provide you with emotional support and understanding. Reach out to trusted friends or family members who can offer a listening ear or even join you in engaging in self-care activities. Online communities or support groups may also be a valuable resource where you can connect with others who are experiencing similar challenges.

Remember, finding what works best for you may take time and patience. It's important to communicate openly with your healthcare provider about your concerns and explore different treatment options together.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Taking care of your mental and emotional well-being is crucial during times of distress.

[Question]
i just can t seem to relax throughout the day every time i think about sitting down and reading watching a tv show meditating putting a face mask on etc i ve got 000 thing on my mind random stuff anxious thought thing i have to get done etcetc so i never get to truly relax i panic just thinking about reading cause it ll be calm and there s nothing to distract me from my thought until i m able to focus on the book which can take a while the only time i m able to actively relax is when i m tired after i ve worked out for h in the gym or late at night got ta find the sweet spot between anxious mess and falling asleep feel like walking a tightrope amp even when i manage to get there i have more important stuff to do than relaxing eg studying amp other stuff that my anxious self didn t manage to do

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be challenging when you're unable to relax throughout the day due to racing thoughts and anxiety. It sounds like your mind is constantly buzzing with tasks, responsibilities, and worries, making it difficult for you to find a sense of calm.

One suggestion I have is to try practicing mindfulness techniques. Mindfulness involves focusing on the present moment without judgment. You can start by setting aside a few minutes each day to simply observe your thoughts and feelings without getting caught up in them. This can help bring your attention back to the present and reduce anxiety.

Another strategy that may be helpful is creating a relaxation routine. This could involve engaging in activities that you enjoy and find calming, such as reading, listening to soothing music, or taking a warm bath. By intentionally incorporating these activities into your daily schedule, you can create dedicated time for relaxation and make it a priority.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to explore any underlying causes of your anxiety. Are there specific triggers or patterns that contribute to your racing thoughts? Keeping a journal where you record your thoughts and emotions throughout the day can help identify these triggers and provide insights into your anxiety.

In terms of finding a balance between relaxation and productivity, it's important to remember that self-care is not selfish. Taking care of your mental and emotional well-being is essential for overall functioning and productivity. Consider setting aside specific blocks of time each day dedicated solely to relaxation and rejuvenation.

Lastly, if you find it difficult to relax even after trying these strategies, it could be helpful to seek support from a mental health professional. They can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, finding a balance takes time and patience. Be kind to yourself during this process and celebrate small victories along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i ve been on venlafaxine for year or so it helped at first but it hasn t helped whatsoever in quite some time i take 0mg in the morning the last month my anxiety and panic ha been absolutely crippling debilitating and unbearable i called the dr today and he called in a prescription to increase me from 0mg to mg i hate taking any medication or pill whatsoever especially increasing a dosage anyone had any good result from a venlafaxine increase after taking the same dosage for such a long time

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and concerned about your situation. It can be challenging when a medication that once helped no longer provides relief. Increasing the dosage of venlafaxine is something that doctors often consider as a potential option, but it's important to keep in mind that everyone's experience with medication is unique.

When considering an increase in dosage, it may be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with your doctor. They can provide guidance based on your individual circumstances and help weigh the potential benefits against any concerns or side effects you may have. It might also be worth discussing alternative treatment options or exploring other medications that could potentially work better for you.

In addition to discussing medication adjustments with your doctor, there are some lifestyle changes you could try to complement your current treatment. Regular exercise, maintaining a healthy diet, getting enough sleep, and practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or mindfulness exercises can all contribute to managing anxiety and panic symptoms.

Finding support from loved ones or joining a support group can also be beneficial. Connecting with others who have similar experiences can offer understanding and encouragement. Additionally, engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment can help improve your overall well-being.

Remember, it's essential to work closely with your doctor to find the right approach for you. They can provide personalized guidance and monitor your progress closely. Keep in mind that everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Be patient with yourself and trust in the process as you navigate through this.

[Question]
i m talking to my psych on monday and i want to do some research into what might work for me i have frequent mild panic attack infrequent but still kind of like once a week once every week severe panic attack and constant anxiety i ve tried a bunch of anxiety med but haven t really found any that worked for me however i haven t tried any in year so there s a chance i ve grown a i wa about during most of my trial and it s been a good year since then so what are were your favorite thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out for support and looking into different treatment options. It can be helpful to gather information and discuss your concerns with your psychologist on Monday.

In terms of researching what might work for you, there are a few things you can consider. Firstly, it could be beneficial to keep a journal or record of your panic attacks and anxiety symptoms. This can help identify any patterns or triggers that you may not have noticed before. Additionally, you might want to explore relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation. These practices can help manage anxiety and reduce the frequency of panic attacks.

Another option to explore is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns that contribute to anxiety and panic attacks. It can provide you with practical strategies to cope with these feelings and improve your overall well-being. You may want to discuss this approach with your psychologist and see if it aligns with your goals and preferences.

Regarding medication, it's important to remember that everyone responds differently to different medications. While you mentioned not finding any anxiety meds that worked for you in the past year, it doesn't mean that they won't work for you now. It could be worth discussing this with your psychologist, who can evaluate your specific situation and suggest appropriate options based on your current needs and medical history.

Lastly, finding a support system can make a significant difference in managing anxiety and panic attacks. Consider reaching out to friends, family, or online communities who may have experienced similar challenges. Sharing your experiences and hearing from others can provide validation and encouragement.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Your psychologist will be able to guide you further based on your individual circumstances. I hope you have a productive discussion on Monday and find the support and strategies that work best for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
it s been so long i have been avoiding to get treated especially because it s social anxiety i definitely don t want to talk to a stranger but it s been ruining my life so here we are any tip anything i should prepare what question do they ask you i am already getting anxiety attack because of the appointment

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can understand how challenging it must be for you to consider seeking treatment for your social anxiety. It's completely normal to feel hesitant about talking to a stranger, especially when it comes to your mental health. However, I want you to know that there are steps you can take to make the process more comfortable.

Firstly, it might help to do some research on the therapist or counselor you plan to see. Look for their qualifications and experience in working with social anxiety. This can give you a sense of trust and confidence in their ability to understand and help you.

Additionally, you could try reaching out to the therapist beforehand to ask any questions you may have. This can provide you with more information about their approach and help alleviate some of your anxiety. You can also discuss any specific concerns or preferences you have regarding the treatment process.

On the day of the appointment, it can be beneficial to arrive a bit early so you have time to gather your thoughts and relax beforehand. Taking deep breaths or practicing relaxation techniques can also help manage any anxiety you may be experiencing.

During the session, remember that the therapist is there to support you and create a safe space for you to express yourself. They will likely ask questions to gain a better understanding of your situation and tailor the treatment to your needs. Try to focus on your breathing and remind yourself that this is an opportunity for growth and healing.

Lastly, don't hesitate to communicate openly with your therapist about your feelings and concerns. They are there to work with you, and your active participation in the process is crucial. Remember, progress takes time, and it's okay to have ups and downs along the way.

I hope these suggestions can help you feel more prepared and empowered as you take this important step towards your well-being. You deserve support and care, and I believe in your ability to overcome social anxiety and lead a fulfilling life.

i am not sure if this is possible and i appreciate any information a few year ago i wa diagnosed with clinical anxiety depression and adhd i wa relieved and terrified and so sad it took me until adulthood to learn this about myself i began medicating under the direction of my psychiatrist after about a year i changed from zoloft to prozac due to weight gain i began experiencing night sweat for the first time in my life about month ago it wa sporadic for month or so than became nightly now it ha worsened to the point that i wake up multiple time a night to change sheet and pajama i m not wetting the bed but truly soaking it through with my sweat in a degree room with minimal blanket i ve had to replace plastic bed protector mattress cover and even my mattress i believe i am having panic attack while i am asleep and i am unable to remember them assuming i would remember having a nightmare at the same time or be semi lucid what could paralyze me in sleep while having normal pleasant dream and cause excessive night sweat my change in medication did not correlate with the onset or increase in the night sweat i have had blood test mri pulmonary exam allergy test ultra sound and more no western doctor or my psychiatrist ha been able to find anything unusual that would explain the night sweat tl dr extreme night sweat begin in adulthood with no obvious cause desperately looking for advice on what might help edit 9 f

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been going through a challenging time with your health, and I can understand how frustrating and overwhelming it must be for you. It's important to remember that I am not a medical professional, but I can offer some suggestions that might help you find some relief from your night sweats.

Firstly, it could be helpful to keep track of when your night sweats occur and try to identify any patterns or triggers. Pay attention to factors such as temperature, stress levels, and even certain foods or drinks you consume before bed. This information may provide some insight into what could be contributing to your night sweats.

In addition, taking care of your overall health can have a positive impact on your sleep and sweating patterns. Regular exercise, maintaining a balanced diet, and getting enough restful sleep can all contribute to better sleep quality. You may also want to consider creating a relaxing bedtime routine to help signal to your body that it's time to wind down and prepare for sleep.

While medication changes can sometimes bring about new symptoms, it's worth exploring other treatment options as well. Some people find relief from night sweats through relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery. These techniques can help reduce anxiety and promote a sense of calmness during sleep.

Additionally, certain lifestyle changes like reducing caffeine intake, avoiding stimulating activities close to bedtime, and keeping your living space cool and comfortable can all potentially alleviate night sweats.

If you haven't already, it might be worth considering reaching out to a healthcare professional who can provide personalized guidance and support. They can evaluate your symptoms more thoroughly and explore additional treatment options that may be suitable for you.

Remember, everyone's experience with night sweats is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to be patient and persistent in your search for relief, and don't hesitate to reach out for professional help if needed.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
guy do any of you also wake up every morning from scary nightmare and feeling completely estranged when you open your eye like your surrounding feel so foreign eventho it s your own home your own room and it take some time for you to realize youre just fine do you wake up with fear every morning

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be really disorienting and unsettling to wake up from a scary nightmare and feel a sense of estrangement, especially when it's in your own home and room. It's understandable that it takes some time for you to realize that you're just fine. Experiencing fear every morning must be quite challenging. Here are a few suggestions that might help:

1. Establish a morning routine: Creating a consistent routine can provide a sense of stability and familiarity in the morning. Include activities that bring you comfort and help ground you, such as stretching, practicing deep breathing exercises, or having a warm cup of tea.

2. Journaling: Consider keeping a journal to record your thoughts and emotions upon waking up. This can help identify any patterns or triggers associated with your nightmares and fears. Additionally, writing down positive affirmations or things you're grateful for can help shift your mindset towards a more positive start to the day.

3. Engage in relaxation techniques: Explore different relaxation techniques like progressive muscle relaxation, guided imagery, or mindfulness meditation. These practices can help calm your mind and body, reducing anxiety and promoting a sense of peace and groundedness.

4. Limit screen time before bed: The content we consume before sleep can significantly impact our dreams and overall well-being. Try to limit exposure to screens, especially electronic devices, at least an hour before going to bed. Instead, engage in calming activities like reading a book or taking a warm bath.

5. Seek support: If these feelings persist or worsen over time, consider reaching out to a trusted friend, family member, or mental health professional who can provide additional guidance and support. Sometimes talking about our experiences and fears can alleviate their intensity.

Remember, everyone's experience is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and know that there is hope for finding relief from these unsettling feelings.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i really need a diagnosis my body hurt sometimes not in a pain way but like a close relative ha died my heart sink my hand shake but it s over a very minor thing my head is saying everything is fine logical but my body feel horrible like i want to burst into tear i d rather physical pain than this i ve broken my finger punching stuff just to snap out of it which work but the best way is for someone to tell me i m wrong tell me that i m thinking stupidly but it s ok and that everything is alright and then it go away this ha happened for a couple year now and i hate it and i need some help it s happening a i write this and i have no one to talk to to feel alright and my head went straight to punching something so i can feel alright again but i know i shouldn t do that i d really appreciate some help

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to assure you that you're not alone. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, but there are some strategies that may help you manage your symptoms.

Firstly, it might be helpful to try deep breathing exercises when you start feeling overwhelmed. Taking slow, deep breaths can help calm your body down and bring your focus back to the present moment. You can try inhaling deeply through your nose for a count of four, holding your breath for a count of four, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth for a count of six.

Another technique that could be beneficial is grounding yourself in the present. When you notice your thoughts starting to spiral, try focusing on your immediate surroundings. Take a moment to notice five things you can see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This exercise can help shift your attention away from anxious thoughts and bring you back to the present moment.

Additionally, finding healthy outlets for your emotions can be important. Engaging in activities that you enjoy and that make you feel good can help distract your mind from anxious thoughts. Whether it's listening to music, practicing yoga, journaling, or spending time in nature, finding something that brings you joy and helps you relax can be incredibly beneficial.

Lastly, reaching out to a trusted friend or family member can provide you with much-needed support. Sometimes just talking about what you're going through can alleviate some of the burden you may be feeling. If you don't feel comfortable discussing this with someone close to you, there are also helplines available where you can speak with trained professionals who can offer guidance and support.

Remember, managing anxiety takes time and patience. It's important to be kind to yourself throughout this process and celebrate even the smallest victories. You deserve support and care, and I encourage you to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide you with personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have gad and have been going through an emotional upheaval with my partner causing extra stress i ve been reducing my lexapro slightly a i felt it wa not working but now am more anxious than ever despite tiny change today i woke up full of dread to go to work no reason i love my job but it all felt too much a a mid ground i decided to work from home today instead of going in i still feel light headed and awful and have the added guilt of messing client around by changing the schedule or converting to online service what do i do how do i get myself to work when it all feel too much

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to offer some guidance and suggestions. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with GAD (Generalized Anxiety Disorder) is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some strategies that you can try to help manage your anxiety and improve your overall well-being.

Firstly, it might be helpful to establish a consistent routine. Having a structured schedule can provide a sense of stability and control, which can be particularly beneficial when dealing with anxiety. Try to set regular times for waking up, eating meals, exercising, and going to bed. This can help regulate your body's internal clock and reduce feelings of uncertainty or overwhelm.

Additionally, incorporating relaxation techniques into your daily routine can be very helpful. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can all help calm your mind and body. You can find guided meditations or relaxation exercises online if you're interested in exploring these practices further.

In terms of managing your anxiety at work, it could be beneficial to break tasks into smaller, more manageable chunks. Prioritize your workload and focus on one task at a time rather than trying to tackle everything at once. Taking short breaks throughout the day can also give you a chance to recharge and reset.

Regarding the guilt you mentioned, it's important to remind yourself that making adjustments to your schedule or offering an online service is not something to feel guilty about. Your mental health should always come first, and sometimes we need to make compromises in order to take care of ourselves. Communicate openly with your clients about any changes that may arise, and assure them that their needs will still be met to the best of your ability.

Lastly, don't hesitate to reach out to supportive friends or family members who can provide emotional support during this challenging time. Sometimes talking to someone we trust can offer a fresh perspective and alleviate some of the burdens we carry.

Remember, these suggestions are just starting points, and it's important to find what works best for you. If you continue to struggle with managing your anxiety and feel overwhelmed, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hey everyone i am just curious if anyone ha also suffered from this type of anxiety i will get anxiety and panic about one thing and after coping and learning to overcome this anxiety my anxiety tends to hyper fixate on something else to worry about im wondering if anyone else ha dealt with this and how they stopped this cycle im currently on sertraline and buspirone and attend therapy a well for anxiety and panic disorder

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're reaching out and seeking support for your anxiety and panic disorder. I can understand how challenging it must be to constantly experience anxiety and panic about different things. It seems like you've already taken some positive steps by being on medication and attending therapy.

One suggestion I have is to try practicing mindfulness techniques. Mindfulness involves focusing on the present moment and observing your thoughts and feelings without judgment. This can help bring your attention away from hyperfixating on worries and allow you to become more aware of what's happening in the present. There are many resources available online, such as guided meditation apps or videos, that can guide you through mindfulness exercises.

Another strategy that might be helpful is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns that contribute to anxiety. By working with a therapist, you can learn to recognize when you're getting caught up in hyperfixation and develop strategies to shift your focus back to the present. Your therapist can provide you with specific techniques tailored to your needs.

Additionally, finding healthy coping mechanisms that work for you can make a big difference. Engaging in activities that you enjoy and help you relax, such as exercise, hobbies, or spending time with loved ones, can provide a much-needed break from anxiety. Taking care of your physical health through proper sleep, nutrition, and exercise can also have a positive impact on your mental well-being.

Remember, everyone's journey with anxiety is unique, so it may take time to find what works best for you. Don't hesitate to communicate openly with your therapist about your concerns and goals. They can offer guidance and support along the way. You're doing great by seeking help and being proactive in managing your anxiety. Keep up the good work!
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
tw depression okay besties i need some help opinion ab my struggle with brushing my hair i currently have really bad knot in my hair and i m hispanic white and my hair is so thick and curly i don t understand how to properly take care of it and i haven t brushed my hair

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be challenging to manage thick and curly hair, especially when there's a knot involved. Here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Start by gently detangling your hair before brushing it. Use a wide-tooth comb or your fingers to gently pull out any tangles.

2. When brushing your hair, use a soft-bristled brush specifically designed for curly hair. This type of brush can help prevent further knots and breakage.

3. Consider using a diffuser attachment when blow-drying your hair. This will help define curls and make it easier to style.

4. Use a wide-tooth comb or your fingers to gently separate and style individual curls rather than trying to brush through them all at once.

5. Avoid using excessive heat on your hair, as this can cause further damage. Instead, try using a lower heat setting on your hair dryer or air-drying your hair whenever possible.

6. Experiment with different hair products, such as conditioners and oils, to find what works best for your hair type. Some people find that coconut oil or argan oil can help moisturize and tame curly hair.

7. Regularly trimming your split ends can also help prevent knots and maintain the overall health of your hair.

Remember, everyone's hair is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find the right techniques and products that work for you. Don't be too hard on yourself if things don't go perfectly - it's all about progress and self-care.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
